page.title: List of IBF Muaythai world champions

revision.comment: adding Mini flyweight (105lbs /47.6kg) and Nadaka Eiwasportgym the 1st champion
revision.text:
{{unsourced|date=December 2017}} This is a '''list of IBF Muay Thai world champions''', showing every world champion certificated by the [[International Boxing Federation Muaythai]] (IBF Muay Thai). The IBF, which is one of the four major governing bodies in professional boxing, started certifying their own [[Muay Thai]] world champions in late 2017. The IBF is the second boxing organization to start certifying Muay Thai World champions following [[World Boxing Council]] (WBC). ==Middleweight (160lbs / 72.5kg)== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|BEL}}{{flagicon|MAR}} Youssef Boughanem | April 28, 2018 | Current |{{age in days |2018|4|28}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Boughanem defeated Payakdum Extra Cole Film ({{THA}}) by TKO(Referee stoppage by forfeit) at 3R at Patong Boxing Stadium in [[Phuket]], [[ Thailand]]. Boughanem retained his Phoenix World Middleweight title too.}} |- |} ==Welterweight (147lbs / 66.7kg)== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|THA}} Pinklao Bangkoknoivillage | December 20, 2017 | Current |{{age in days |2017|12|20}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Pinklao defeated Pinngern Sithchefbuntam ({{THA}}) by decision in the event of "IBF Championship" at [[Suan Lum Night Bazaar]] in [[Bangkok, Thailand]].
He became the 1st IBF Muaythai champion in the history[https://www.facebook.com/muaysiamnews/photos/a.407188216070733.1073741888.128079537314937/1436199513169593/?type=3 IBF CHAMPIONSHIP DEcember 20, 2017].}} |- |} ==Junior welterweight== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|THA}} Darky Lukmakamwan | February 13, 2018 | Current |{{age in days |2018|2|13}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Darky (aka Daakee) defeated Kayyasith Kiatcharoenchai ({{THA}}) by decision after 5R at [[Lumpinee Stadium]] in [[Bangkok, Thailand]][https://www.facebook.com/ibfmt/photos/a.1832039376829586.1073741828.1832031163497074/1853135178053339/?type=3&permPage=1 Darky Lukmakamwan won by point over Kayyasith Kiatcharoenchai.][https://www.facebook.com/ibfmt/posts/1857345284298995 Watch the fight of Darky Lukmakamwan won by point over Kayyasith Kiatcharoenchai.].}} |- |} ==Lightweight (135lbs/ 61.2kg)== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|THA}} Seksan Aor.Kwanmuang | December 21, 2017 | Current |{{age in days |2017|12|21}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Seksan (aka Seksan Or.Kwanmuang) defeated Phanpayak Sitchefboonthum (aka Panpayak Sitchefboontam) ({{THA}}) by decision in the event of "72nd Anniversary of Rajadamnern Stadium Memorial Event" at [[Rajadamnern Stadium]] in [[Bangkok, Thailand]][https://www.facebook.com/davicho.cho.9/posts/300036877170930 'IBF Muay Thai' 135lbs CHAMPIONSHIP!].}} |- |} ==Junior lightweight (130lbs /58.9kg)== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|THA}} Petchaouthong Aor. Kwanmaung | December 21, 2017 | Current |{{age in days |2017|12|21}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Petchaouthong (aka Pet-U-Tong Or. Kwanmuang) defeated Gaonar PK.Saenchaimuaythai (aka Kaonar PK.Saenchaimuaythai) ({{THA}}) by decision in the event of "72nd Anniversary of Rajadamnern Stadium Memorial Event" at [[Rajadamnern Stadium]] in [[Bangkok, Thailand]].
Petchaouthong retained his Rajadamnern Stadium lightweight title[https://www.facebook.com/Singpatongperu/videos/2060739110876118/ RAJADAMNERN AND IBF MUAY THAI 130lbs CHAMPIONSHIP!].}} |- |} ==Mini flyweight (105lbs /47.6kg)== {| class="wikitable" width=100% |- ! style="width:1%;"|No. ! style="width:37%;"|Name ! style="width:20%;"|Date winning ! style="width:20%;"|Date losing ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Days ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:10%;"|Defenses |- align=center !1 |align=left | {{flagicon|JPN}} Nadaka Eiwasportsgym (Nadaka Yoshinari) | September 26, 2018 | Current |{{age in days |2018|9|26}} |0 |- |colspan="6"|{{small|Nadaka defeated Roma Uddonmuang ({{THA}}) by TKO(Referee stoppage Left body shot) at 1R at "Chefboonthum" at [[Rajadamnern Stadium]] in [[Bangkok, Thailand]].
Nadaka was the current [[WBC Muaythai]] World [[Mini flyweight]] champion{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ibfmt/photos/a.1832039376829586/2150602278306626/?type=3&__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARD8pL6NM_XxJm_Iq0gox_77fvpKAULAm58_qKRFftkWhisRmUS-Flo7Q37q43PIqcDAbVFfelEtOQ2esuTrFerEy9qLhcAZ3g3rauUJIX5D2jm54iopYFVHxvHxIAT_PKIW4f98d_EfX01dyxGY7jQ7tdjT5Cvld4kOp4CwGMnuc-kT4Kg-kg&__tn__=-R|title=Congratulation to The IBF Muay Thai Mini Flyweight World Champion Nadaka Eiwasportgym|language=en|date=2018-09-27|website=facebook.com/ibfmt|access-date=2018-09-28}} {{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ibfmt/photos/a.1832039376829586/2150632581636929/?type=3&__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARAkpPHyNKVHjNCsylNgLHQEOlQKhVEU90kivwnQXwTGlBUqd_IICUykoDzKpURWyq6riSILbToYdRC0GNiWkAofFJmwo75hd-E9btuCiZ2LjCKWyeZZUbI7xrxF2Tve4YGVQbRIPRq5-rzMctfhkSUBINrfWinL1l8kLy5J86g8m3gh4-eVsA&__tn__=-R|title=Nadaka Eiwasportgyn is Japan's first IBF Muay Thai World champion. |language=en|date=2018-09-27|website=facebook.com/ibfmt|access-date=2018-09-28}}}} |- |} == See also == *[[List of IBF world champions]] (boxing champions) *[[List of WBC Muaythai world champions]] *[[List of current world Muaythai champions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:International Boxing Federation champions|*]] [[Category:Lists of sportspeople|IBF Muay Thai world champions]] [[Category:Lists of kickboxers|IBF Muaythai world champions]] [[Category:Muay Thai]]

{{Infobox tennis cup team|Type = Davis | Name = Montenegro | Image = Flag of Montenegro.svg | Nickname = | Captain = Balsa Milosevic | Coach = | ITF Rank = 76 {{increase}}8 | ITF max = | ITF max date = | ITF min = | ITF min date = | Colors = red & yellow | First year = [[2007 Davis Cup|2007]] | Years played = 12 | Ties played = 44 (29–14) | WG played = | Titles = | Runners-up = | Best = Europe/Africa Zone group II
first round ([[2009 Davis Cup Europe/Africa Zone Group II|2009]]) | Player wins = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] (31–9) | Singles wins = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] (19–7) | Doubles wins = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] (12–2) | Best doubles = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] &
[[Nemanja Kontić]] (4–0) | Most ties = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] (29) | Most years = [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] (9) }} The '''Montenegro Davis Cup team''' represents [[Montenegro]] in [[Davis Cup]] [[tennis]] competition and are governed by the [[Tennis Federation of Montenegro]]. Montenegro made its debut in Davis Cup in [[2007 Davis Cup|2007]] in the Europe/Africa Zone of Group IV. In competition of Andorra, Armenia, Botswana and Rwanda, Montenegro finished first with all four victories, with losing only one set in twelve matches played. In 2008, Montenegro competed in the Europe/Africa Zone of Group III. With four victories and one defeat from host [[Bulgaria Davis Cup team|Bulgaria]], Montenegro was second in Venue 1 and was promoted to Europe/Africa Zone of Group II. In 2009, Montenegro lost first round tie to [[Monaco Davis Cup team|Monaco]] 5–0 at Monte Carlo Country Club, Roquebrune Cap Martin, and had to play relegation play-off against [[Denmark Davis Cup team|Denmark]]. The tie came to the decisive match, which Montenegro lost in straight sets, and with the final score 2–3 Montenegro lost its second tie in the second group, which led to relegation back to Europe Zone Group III. In 2013 Montenegro played they only one draw against [[San Marino Davis Cup team|San Marino]], because after two matches, the last game was not played for heavy rains.{{cite news|title=Coppa Davis: San Marino - Montenegro 1-1|url=http://www.smtvsanmarino.sm/sport/altri-sport/2013/05/25/coppa-davis-san-marino-montenegro-1-1|publisher=www.smtvsanmarino.sm|language=Italian|date=25 May 2013|accessdate=27 October 2017}} ==Current team== * [[Ljubomir Čelebić]] * Pavle Rogan * Stefan Dragović * [[Rrezart Cungu]] ==History== Montenegro has competed in its first Davis Cup in 2007. Montenegro previously competed as part of [[Serbia and Montenegro Davis Cup team|Serbia and Montenegro]] and before that, as part of [[Yugoslavia Davis Cup team|Yugoslavia]]. == Matches == Full list of Montenegrin Davis Cup team matches (since independence): {| class="wikitable" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox sportsperson |name=Noppie Koch |image=Noppie Koch 1967.jpg | image_size = |caption=Noppie Koch in 1967 |birth_date=22 March 1932 |birth_place=[[Utrecht]], the Netherlands |death_date=7 December 2010 (aged 78) |death_place=[[Nieuwegein]], the Netherlands | height = | weight = |sport=[[Motor-paced racing]] |club= |alma_mater= | show-medals = yes | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry | the {{NED}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[UCI Motor-paced World Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze | 1959 Amsterdam |Professionals}} {{MedalBronze | 1960 Leipzig|Professionals}} }} '''Longinus Johannes Norbert "Noppie" Koch''' (22 March 1932 – 7 December 2010) was a cyclist and pacer from the Netherlands. As a cyclist he became national champion in 1959, 1962 and 1963 and won two bronze medals at the [[UCI Motor-paced World Championships]] in 1959 and 1960, in the professionals category.<ref name=r3/> He was then injured in an accident at the factory where he worked and had to retire from racing. He became a pacer in [[motor-paced racing]], bringing [[Piet de Wit]], [[Leo Proost]], [[Martin Venix]] and [[Mattheus Pronk]] to the [[UCI Motor-paced World Championships]] titles.<ref name=r1/><ref name=r2/>
His fame as a pacemaker spread beyond the Netherlands, and he was invited to work with German and Belgian cyclists such as [[Dieter Kemper]], [[Theo Verschueren]] and [[Stan Tourné]].<ref name=r1/><ref name=r2/> Although UCI required the pacer and the cyclist to be from the same country, Koch, together with another international pacer [[Bruno Walrave]], successfully argued in the Dutch court to remove this rule. The basis for the claim was that Koch and Walrave would lose their jobs as pacers because of the discrimination by their nationality.<ref name=r4/>
In total, as a pacer Koch won 10 world and 14 European titles between 1965 and 1987. He retired in 1988/1989 after being injured in a crash during a race.
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=r1>[http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2698/Sport/article/detail/1069823/2010/12/07/Gangmaker-Norbert-Koch-overleden.dhtml Gangmaker Norbert Koch overleden]. Volkskrant (2010-12-07).</ref> <ref name=r2>Fred van Slogteren (2010-12-07). [http://wielersport.slogblog.nl/post/1/4192 Noppie Koch (1932–2010)]. slogblog.nl</ref> <ref name=r3>[http://www.radsportseiten.net/coureurfiche.php?coureurid=8441 Norbert Koch]. radsportseiten.net</ref> <ref name=r4>[http://www.asser.nl/default.aspx?site_id=11&level1=13912&level2=13963 02.10.01. Report on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens’ rights on the freedom of movement of professional footballers in the community, 1 March 1989]. asser.nl</ref> }} [[File:Noppie Koch and Martin Venix 1979b.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Noppie Koch with Martin Venix at the 1979 World Championships]] {{Commons category}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Koch, Noppie}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch male cyclists]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Utrecht (city)]] [[Category:Pacemakers]]

The '''Olympic medal table''' is a method of sorting the medal placements of countries in the modern-day [[Olympic Games|Olympics]] and [[Paralympic Games|Paralympics]]. The [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) does not officially recognize a ranking of participating countries at the Olympic Games.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite news |last=Johnson|first=Ian|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121856271893833843?mod=psp_free_today&mg=com-wsj#printMode|title=Who's on First in Medals Race|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 13, 2008|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref> Nevertheless, the IOC does publish medal tallies for information purposes, showing the total number of [[Olympic medal]]s earned by athletes representing each country's respective [[National Olympic Committee]].<ref name="Araton">{{Cite news|last=Araton|first=Harvey|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/19/sports/olympics/19araton.html?_r=2&ref=sports&pagewanted=print|title=A Medal Count That Adds Up To Little|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 18, 2008|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref> The convention used by the IOC is to sort by the number of gold medals the athletes from a country have earned. In the event of a tie in the number of gold medals, the number of silver medals is taken into consideration, and then the number of bronze medals. If two countries have an equal number of gold, silver, and bronze medals, they are ordered in the table alphabetically by their [[List of IOC country codes|IOC country code]].
==Background== The Olympic Charter, Chapter 1, section 6 states that: {{bquote|The Olympic Games are competitions between athletes in individual or team events and not between countries...<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.olympic.org/Documents/olympic_charter_en.pdf|title=Olympic Charter|publisher=''International Olympic Committee''|date=2011-07-08|accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref>}} The Charter goes even further in Chapter 5, section 57, expressly prohibiting the IOC from producing an official ranking: {{bquote|The IOC and the OCOG shall not draw up any global ranking per country. A roll of honour bearing the names of medal winners and those awarded diplomas in each event shall be established by the OCOG and the names of the medal winners shall be featured prominently and be on permanent display in the main stadium.}}
According to Australian IOC member [[Kevan Gosper]], the IOC began to accommodate medals tables in 1992, releasing 'information' based on the 'gold first' standard.<ref name="WSJ"/> The medal tables provided on its website carry this disclaimer: {{bquote|The International Olympic Committee (IOC) does not recognise global ranking per country; the medal tables are displayed for information only. Furthermore, the results that we publish are official and are taken from the "Official Report" - a document published for each Olympic Games by the Organising Committee. However, for the first Olympic Games (until Antwerp in 1920), it is difficult to give the exact number of medals awarded to some countries since teams were composed of athletes from different countries. The medal tables by country are based on the number of medals won, with gold medals taking priority over silver and bronze. A team victory counts as one medal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.olympic.org/uk/games/past/table_uk.asp?OLGT=1&OLGY=1896|title=Olympic Games Athens 1896 - Medal Table|publisher=''International Olympic Committee''|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>}}
===Official reports=== Each [[OCOG|Olympic Games organising committee]] (except in 1904) has published an official report after the conclusion of the Games, which among other things list the results of each event. Some early reports included an overall national ranking, including those of 1908,<ref name="officialreport1908">{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1908/1908.pdf#page=418|title=Official Report|last=1908 Olympic Games Organising Committee|pages=366–7|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> 1912,<ref name="officialreport1912">{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1912/1912.pdf#page=1178|title=Official Report|last=1912 Olympic Games Organising Committee|pages=864–5|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> 1924 (Summer<ref name="officialreport1924s">{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1924/1924.pdf#page=615|title=Official Report|last=1924 Summer Olympic Games Organising Committee|page=617|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> and Winter<ref name="officialreport1924w">{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1924/1924part4.pdf#page=60|title=Official Report|last=1924 Winter Olympic Games Organising Committee|pages=661|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref>) and 1928 (Winter<ref name="officialreport1928">{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1928/1928w2.pdf#page=19|title=Official Report|last=1928 Winter Olympic Games Organising Committee|page=19|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref>). The 1912 and 1924 tables are described as "official" while that of 1928 is "unofficial".
The 1932 Winter Games report states, "There is no official point score in the Olympic Games" and quotes General Rule 19 of the 1930 Olympic Charter, "In the Olympic Games there is no classification according to points".<ref name="officialreport1932w">{{cite book|last=Latimer|first=George M.|title=Report |url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1932/1932w.pdf#page=264|year=1932|publisher=III Olympic Winter Games Organizing Committee|location=Lake Placid|pages=264–5|chapter=Point Scoring}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Olympic%20Charter/Olympic_Charter_through_time/1930-Olympic_Charter.pdf#page=12|title=General rules applicable to the celebration of the Olympic Games|year=1930|work=1930 - Olympic Charter - Statutes of the International Olympic Committee|publisher=International Olympic Committee|page=28|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> It states that the country-based organisation of teams is "chiefly for practical convenience" and that country rankings are "a grave injustice on the smaller countries".<ref name="officialreport1932w"/> It continues that "it has been the experience of all previous Olympic Games that the press of the world insist on exploiting the aspect of national rivalry by creating and publishing a wholly unofficial point score of their own devising, most often on the basis of 10, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 points for the six places recognized on the table of honor". The report itself provides such a table "for ready reference".<ref name="officialreport1932w"/>
===National goals=== The sports funding agencies of some nations have set targets of reaching a certain rank in the medals table, usually based on gold medals; examples are Australia, Japan, France, and Germany.<ref name="WSJ"/> Funding is reduced for sports with low prospects of medals.<ref name="WSJ"/>
After London's [[London bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics|successful bid]] to host the [[2012 Olympics]], [[UK Sport]] submitted a funding request to the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] setting an "aspirational goal" of fourth place in the [[2012 Summer Olympics medal table|2012 medals table]], to be reviewed after the [[2008 Olympics]], for which a target of eighth place was set.<ref name="nao2008">{{cite web|url=https://www.nao.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/0708434.pdf#page=27|title=Setting targets and reporting performance|last=Comptroller and auditor general|date=20 March 2008|work=Preparing for Sporting Success at the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games and Beyond|publisher=[[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]]|pages=25, sec 3.4–3.5|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="cm200708">{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmcumeds/104/7120414.htm|title=Memorandum submitted by the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Ltd (LOCOG)|last=Select Committee on Culture, Media and Sport|date=4 December 2007|work=House of Commons|pages=Minutes of Evidence Examination of Witnesses Questions 220–239|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmpubacc/477/47703.htm|title=Forty-Second Report|last=Select Committee on Public Accounts|date=23 June 2008|work=House of Commons|page=Summary|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> The [[British Olympic Association]] dissociated itself from setting targets.<ref name="cm200708"/> When Britain [[Great Britain at the 2008 Summer Olympics|finished fourth in 2008]], the 2012 target was settled at fourth, with the team [[Great Britain at the 2012 Summer Olympics|ultimately finishing third]].
[[Australia at the 2012 Summer Olympics|Australia's disappointing 10th-place]] in the 2012 medals table prompted the [[Australian Sports Commission]] to draw up a ten-year plan which included a "medium-term" goal of a top-five place in the Summer Olympics and Paralympics and a top-15 place in the winter games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ausport.gov.au/ais/rio_2016|title=Rio 2016|last=Wylie|first=John|year=2015|publisher=Australian Sports Commission (republished from [[The Australian]])|accessdate=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160227031003/http://ausport.gov.au/ais/rio_2016#|archive-date=2016-02-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ausport.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/509852/Australias_Winning_Edge.pdf#page=4|title=Australia’s 2012–2022 performance targets|year=2012|work=Australia's Winning Edge 2012–2022|publisher=Australian Sports Commission|page=4|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref>
When [[Tokyo bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics]], the [[Japanese Olympic Committee]] set a 2016 target of third place in gold medals, which it retained even after the games were awarded in 2009 to Rio de Janeiro.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2010/04/28/olympics/joc-wont-change-gold-medal-target-for-2016-olympics/#.VtoemX2LRhF|title=JOC won't change gold medal target for 2016 Olympics|date=28 April 2010|work=The Japan Times|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref>
==Ranking systems== {{Quote box|width=250px|align=right|quote="I believe each country will highlight what suits it best. One country will say, 'Gold medals.' The other country will say, 'The total tally counts.' We take no position on that."|source='''[[IOC]] President [[Jacques Rogge]]'''<ref name=Rogge>{{cite news|last=Shipley|first=Amy|title=China's Show of Power|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 25, 2008|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/24/AR2008082400851_pf.html|accessdate=2008-08-28}}</ref> }}
As the IOC does not consider its sorting of nations to be an official ranking system, various methods of ranking nations are used. Some sort rankings decided by the total number of medals the country has but most list by the gold medals counted. However, if two or more teams have the same number of gold medals, the silver medals are then judged from the most to the least and then the bronze medals.
=== Medal count ranking === The '''gold first''' ranking system described above is used by most of the world media, as well as the IOC. While the gold first ranking system has been used occasionally by some American media outlets, newspapers in the United States primarily publish medal tables ordered by the '''total number''' of medals won.<ref>{{cite news|last=Eason|first=Kevin|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/olympics/article4599875.ece?print=yes&randnum=1268512737712|title=America refuses to accept defeat in Olympic medal count|publisher=''The Times (UK)''|date=2008-08-25|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Flyan|first=Kevin|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/china/2008/08/19/whos-top-of-the-medals-table/|title=Who’s top of the medals table?|publisher=Reuters|date=2008-08-19|accessdate=2009-01-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916020810/http://blogs.reuters.com/china/2008/08/19/whos-top-of-the-medals-table/|archivedate=2008-09-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wetzel|first=Dan|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/news;_ylt=Av5FIN9FAQzc5PVxJGoYmla7KZt4?slug=dw-medalcount082208&prov=yhoo&type=lgns&print=1|title=U.S. will be rocked by China’s heavy medals|publisher=''Yahoo! Sports''|date=2008-08-22|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Pells|first=Eddie|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2008-03-05-2600371400_x.htm|title=US, China set low Olympic expectations|publisher=USA Today|date=March 5, 2008|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Alan|url=http://www.2008.nbcolympics.com/destinationbeijing/blogs/postid=221688.html#different+measures+success+race+gold|title=Different measures of success in race for gold |publisher=NBC Olympics|date=2008-08-16|accessdate=2010-01-10}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/olympics/2602029/US-accused-of-medal-table-spin---Beijing-Olympics-2008.html|accessdate=2009-01-16|date=2008-08-22|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|publisher=''The Telegraph (UK)''|title=US accused of medal table spin}}</ref>
This difference in rankings has its origins in the early days of the Olympics, when the IOC did not publish or recognise medal tables.<ref name="WSJ"/> Before the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] the difference in ranking system received scant notice, since in recent Olympic history the country that led in total medals also led in the gold count.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} However, during the 2002 Winter Olympics Germany won the highest number of medals (36), but earned one gold medal fewer than Norway - the latter winning 13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databaseolympics.com/games/gamesyear.htm?g=45 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418064015/http://www.databaseolympics.com/games/gamesyear.htm?g=45 |archivedate=2008-04-18 |df= }}</ref> A similar situation occurred at the [[2008 Summer Olympics medal table|2008 Summer Olympics]], with China and U.S. topping the gold and total medal tallies respectively,<ref name="times">{{cite news|first=Robert |last=Hardaway |title=Weighing Olympic gold |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/sunday/commentary/la-oe-hardaway22-2008aug22,0,52982.story |publisher=''The Los Angeles Times'' |date=2008-08-22 |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827043408/http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/sunday/commentary/la-oe-hardaway22-2008aug22%2C0%2C52982.story |archivedate=August 27, 2008 |df= }}</ref> and then again at the [[2010 Winter Olympics medal table|2010 Winter Olympics]] when Canada and the U.S. finished 1st and 3rd respectively in the "gold first" ranking<ref>[http://www.sochi2014.com/en/medal-history?year=2010 2010 Official Medal Table]</ref> and 3rd and 1st respectively in terms of total medals won.<ref name="Vancouver 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-medals/ |title=Official Website for the Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics |accessdate=2010-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212034642/http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-medals/ |archivedate=2010-02-12 |df= }}</ref> Other exceptions are the [[1896 Summer Olympics medal table|1896]], [[1912 Summer Olympics medal table|1912]], and [[1964 Summer Olympics medal table|1964]] Summer Olympics when the United States finished first in gold medal count, but second in the overall medal count. In an August 24, 2008 news conference, IOC President [[Jacques Rogge]] confirmed that the IOC does not have a view on any particular ranking system.<ref name=Rogge/>
=== Population-size, resources-per-person and multivariate prediction models and ratings=== Sporting success predictions and ratings can be [[univariate]], i.e. based on one independent variable, such as a country's population size and the number of medals is divided by the population of the country,<ref name=nzherald>{{cite web|title=We are second in medals table-behind Slovenia|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10528184|accessdate=2009-01-16|date=2008-08-21|publisher=New Zealand Herald|last=Donovan|first=Brooke}}</ref><ref name=guardianrogers>{{cite web|title=Olympics 2012: the alternative medals table|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/datablog/2012/jul/30/olympics-2012-alternative-medal-table#pop|accessdate=2012-08-06|date=2012-08-30|publisher=''The Guardian''|last=Rogers|first=Simon}}</ref> or [[wikt:multivariate|multivariate]], where resources-per-person in the form of GDP per capita and other variables are included. <!--Since the following portion of text seems to be original research and no references were given, and also the argument presented is - as I have shown at the end - double-edged one: Every country is limited in the number of participants they can send per event, sometimes as few as one athlete per event, including one team in team events. Countries with a large population, such as China or the United States, usually do not rank highly here,<ref name=nzherald>{{cite web|title=We are second in medals table-behind Slovenia|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10528184|accessdate=2009-01-16|date=2008-08-21|publisher=New Zealand Herald|last=Donovan|first=Brooke}}</ref> since they cannot send as many participants per capita as some smaller countries, but on the other hand smaller nations have to select the best competitors from much smaller population to compete with the best from bigger nations.-->
Resources per person in the form of [[GDP]] per capita has been included in an article by ''[[The Guardian]]'' published during the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]<ref name=guardianrogers>{{cite web|title=Olympics 2012: the alternative medals table|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/datablog/2012/jul/30/olympics-2012-alternative-medal-table#pop|accessdate=2012-08-06|date=2012-08-30|publisher=''The Guardian''|last=Rogers|first=Simon}}</ref> and again by [[Google]]'s News Lab for the Rio 2016 games.<ref name=flagandmap>{{cite web|title=2008 Summer Olympics: GDP Adjusted Performance Ranking|url=http://www.flagandmap.com/famcore/olympics-2008-gdpadj-ranking|accessdate=2012-07-25|publisher=FlagAndMap}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://landing.google.com/altmedaltable/|title=Alternative Olympics medal table|website=landing.google.com|access-date=2016-08-13}}</ref> Already in 2002, the research done by Meghan Busse of [[Northwestern University]] suggested that both a large population and high per capita GDP are needed to generate high medal totals,<ref>[http://mba.tuck.dartmouth.edu/pages/faculty/andrew.bernard/olymp60restat_finaljournalversion.pdf Who Wins the Olympic Games: Economic Resources and Medal Totals], ''Review of Economics and Statistics'', December 2002.</ref> and predictive models have been built trying to predict success with [[multivariate analysis]], taking also past results and host-nation advantage into account.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18976333 |title=Medals table: The alternative rankings for London 2012 |publisher=The BBC |date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradocollege.edu/newsevents/newsroom/dan-johnson-the-man-who-predicts-medals |title=Dan Johnson: "The Man Who Predicts Medals" |publisher=Colorado College |date=18 July 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19249898 |title=Medals table: The real winners and losers |publisher=The BBC |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref>
=== Weighted ranking === Systematic rankings based upon a weighted point system with the most points awarded to a gold medal have also been devised. Those used in the official reports were: * 1908: 5:3:1 — gold medals 5 points, silver medals 3 points, and bronze medals 1 point.<ref name="officialreport1908"/><ref name="times"/> * 1912: 3:2:1 — the report also compares this "Swedish" method with the 5:3:1 "English" method.<ref name="officialreport1912"/> * 1924: 10:5:4:3:2:1 — so points were awarded for 4th to 6th places, where no medals were awarded.<ref name="officialreport1924s"/><ref name="officialreport1924w"/> The IOC did require top six finishers to be listed in the report in a "table of honor".<ref name="officialreport1932w"/> * 1928: 6:5:4:3:2:1 — separate totals are listed depending on whether the [[military patrol]] was included or not, as [[Military patrol at the 1928 Winter Olympics|its status was downgraded]] belatedly to [[demonstration sport]].<ref name="officialreport1928"/> * 1932: same as 1924, and described as the usual scheme in newspapers.<ref name="officialreport1932w"/> The 1908 and 1924 systems share the points for tied placings: for example, in a two-way tie for second, each gets half the sum of the points for second and third place.<ref name="officialreport1908"/><ref name="officialreport1924s"/><ref name="officialreport1924w"/>
In 2004, a 3:2:1 system was used by the Australian Geography Teachers Association.<ref name="AGTA">{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Bernard |title=Medal points data for Athens 2004 Olympic Games |url=http://www.geography.org.uk/download/GA_PSMMAthensPoints.pdf |publisher=Review of Economics and Statistics |year=2004 |accessdate=2010-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719003703/http://www.geography.org.uk/download/GA_PSMMAthensPoints.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref> This weighting values a gold medal as much weight as a silver and a bronze medal combined. In response to the 2008 controversy over medal rank, Jeff Z. Klein in a ''[[New York Times]]'' blog post proposed a 4:2:1 system as a compromise between the total-medals and golds-first methods.<ref name="NYT">{{cite web |title=The Medal Rankings: Which Country Leads the Olympics?|author=Klein, Jeff |publisher=''New York Times''|date=2008-08-17 |url=http://beijing2008.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/23/the-medal-rankings-which-country-leads-the-olympics/|accessdate=2010-01-10}}</ref> These systems have been popular in certain places at certain times, but none of them have been adopted on a large scale.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} The '''International Roll of Honour''' is a list established by the [[Scottish Football Association]] recognising players who have gained 50 or more international [[cap (football)|caps]] for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. The roll of honour was launched in February 1988, when 11 players had already achieved the distinction.{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_football_players.cfm?page=138 |publisher=[[Scottish Football Association]]|accessdate=11 March 2017|title=International Roll of Honour |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427032517/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_football_players.cfm?page=138 |archivedate=27 April 2011}} Each player inducted receives a commemorative gold medal, an invitation to every Scotland home match and has their portrait hung in the [[Scottish Football Museum]]. {{as of|2018}} there are 31 players on the roll of honour. [[Craig Gordon]] is the most recent addition, having won his 50th cap on 5 October 2017 against [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]]. In July 2017, the SFA launched the Women's International Roll of Honour, which recognises players who have won 100 or more caps for [[Scotland women's national football team|Scotland Women's National Team]]. The women's roll of honour initially included 12 players.{{cite web |url=https://www.scottishfa.co.uk/news/women-s-international-roll-of-honour-unveiled/ |title=Women’s International Roll of Honour unveiled |work= |publisher=Scottish Football Association |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=23 October 2018}} ==Players on the roll of honour== ;Key {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background-color:#FFCCCC"|* |Still [[Scotland national football team#Current squad|active for the national team]] |} {{updated|23:40, 20 November 2018 (UTC)}} {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="3" style="text-align: center;" |- !Rank !Player !Ref !ClubsOnly clubs the players were with when they received full international caps are included. !Scotland career !Year entered !Caps |- |1 |align=left|{{sortname|Kenny|Dalglish}} |{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/scot-intres1980.html |title=Scotland - {{Infobox venue | name = Silivrikapi Ice Skating Hall | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = SilivrikapıIceRink (6).JPG | caption = Silvirikapı Ice Rink in Fatih, Istanbul | fullname = Silivrikapi Skating Hall and Recreation Center | former_names = | location = Silivrikapi, [[Fatih]], [[Istanbul Province]], Turkey | coordinates = {{coord|41.00344|N|28.92208|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{Start date|2007}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|2009}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality | operator = | surface = {{convert|8950|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} | scoreboard = | cost = {{Turkish lira}} 30 million (approx. US$20 million) | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 900 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} {{Location map | Turkey Istanbul | width = | float = | border = | caption = Location of Silivrikapi Ice Skating Hall in Istanbul, Turkey | alt = | relief = | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = Silivrikapi Ice Skating Hall | label_size = | position = | background = | mark = Blackskate.svg | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 41.00344 | lat_dir= N | lon_deg = 28.92208 | lon_dir= E }} [[File:SilivrikapıIceRink (24).JPG|thumb|A view from the inside of Silivrikapı Ice Rink.]] '''Silivrikapi Ice Skating Hall''', full name '''Silivrikapi Skating Hall and Recreation Center''', shortly '''Silivrikapı Ice Rink''', ({{lang-tr|Silivrikapı Buz Pateni Salonu}}), is an indoor [[ice skating]] and [[ice hockey]] [[hockey rink|arena]] located at Silivrikapı neighborhood of [[Fatih]] district in [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]]. It was opened in September 2009.<ref name="ibb">{{cite web |url=http://www.ibb.gov.tr/en-US/Pages/Haber.aspx?NewsID=191 |publisher=Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality |title=Silivrikapı Ice Rink Ready for Championship… |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref>
The arena consists of an Olympic-size rink of {{convert|1740|m2|sqft |abbr=on}} with a seating capacity of 900 people, and another one of {{convert|600|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} for 200 spectators used as training rink.<ref name="hdn">{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=istanbul-waits-20-years-for-first-faceoff-2010-01-03 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |title=Istanbul waits 20 years for first faceoff |date=2012-01-03 |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref>
Covering an area of {{convert|8950|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}, the construction of the complex cost {{Turkish lira}} 30 million (approx. US$20 million).<ref name="ibb"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icepark.com.tr/tuerkiyeden-haberler/27-slvrkapi-buz-pst.html |publisher=Ice Park |title=Silivrikapı Buz Pisti |language=Turkish |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref>
==History== Asked by the [[Turkish Ice Skating Federation]], the Metropoiitan Municipality of Istanbul planned to build an ice rink in 1989. The district municipality of Fatih allocated the current site for the building of the venue. However, the government was reluctant to provide the funds required. The planning and the works proceeded only slow since the project proved to be difficult due to lack of technical know-how about the construction of an ice rink.<ref name="hdn"/>
Shortly before the completion of the construction, a major [[1999 İzmit earthquake|earthquake in 1999]] devastated parts of Istanbul. Due to an expertise, the building was declared unsafe. The structure was then demolished, and the project was abandoned.<ref name="hdn"/>
Years after, the project to build an ice rink resumed with pressure from the ice skating community and financial support from the government. In 2007, the construction of a new ice skating venue began at the same site in Silivrikapı that was finally completed in September 2009. Shortly after its opening, the venue hosted [[International Skating Union]]'s Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating event.<ref name="ibb"/><ref name="hdn"/>
Silivrikapı Ice Skating Hall hosts ice hockey clubs of Istanbul, which carried out their trainings in the past at the [[Galleria Ice Rink]], a small size ice rink in a shopping mall not far from the Silivrikapı Arena.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eurohockey.com/club/2203-istanbul-paten-klb.html?league=847 |publisher=Euro Hockey |title=Istanbul Paten Klübü |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref>
==International events hosted== * [[2009–2010 ISU Junior Grand Prix#Qualifying|15th Junior Grand Prix Bosphorus]] October 14–18, 2009<ref name="hdn"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isuresults.com/results/jgptur2009/ |publisher=ISU Results |title=ISU Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating 2009/2010 Bosphorus |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref> * [[2010 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships – Division III]] January 4–10, 2010 * [[2016 IIHF World Championship Division III]] March 31 – April 6, 2016
==Places of interest== * [[Walls of Constantinople]], Silivrikapı (literally: [[Silivri]] Gate) is a gate of the old city walls in the west, * [[Abdi İpekçi Arena]]
==Transport== * City bus lines 93, 93C, 93M and 93T serve the venue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sporas.com.tr/tesisler.aspx?pid=227&tid=295 |publisher=Spor AŞ |title=Silivrikapı Buz Pisti ve Spor Tesisi |language=Turkish |accessdate=2012-10-18 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Silivrikapı Ice Rink}}

{{orphan|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = The Bookmaker Ratings | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Daily sports newspaper | format = Analytical website | owners = Paruyr Shahbazyan | founder = | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = Bradley Gibbs | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 1 March 2012 | political = | language = [[Russian language|Russian]], [[English language|English]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = {{URL|https://bookmaker-ratings.com/}} }}
'''Bookmaker Ratings''' - the international analytical online publication which mediates disputes between players and bookmakers. Bookmaker Ratings was founded by Paruyr Shahbazyan in 2012 when he spent $50 purchasing a simple website template.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paruyr Shahbazyan in Forbes |url=http://www.forbes.ru/finansy/309505-na-storone-igroka-kak-zarabotat-v-bukmekerskom-biznese}}</ref> Also in 2012, Bookmaker Ratings made the news after being informed of a possible match-fixing incident in the Russian championship between Khimki and Petrotrest. Later, UEFA asked them to investigate the match between these two sides in order to identify any incidents. Bookmaker Ratings does not only try to solve disputes between players and bookmakers but also has an independent rating system<ref>{{cite web|title= Interview with Paruyr Shahbazyan|url=http://sobesednik.ru/sport/20120404-totalizatory-onlain-novye-instrumenty-dlya-regulirovaniya-rynka}}</ref> where bookmakers are ranked from 1 to 5 on several criteria including: reliability, speed of payments, customer support and value of odds. This system of ratings is regularly updated, including new bookmaking companies.
The website, which is available in four languages, publishes daily betting tips for various sports, written by the site's authors who range from journalists to ex-players including commentator [[Konstantin Genich]] and former world number 5 tennis player [[Anna Chakvetadze]]. Other experts in the past have included football World Cup winner [[Fabio Cannavaro]] and former heavyweight boxing champion [[Nikolai Valuev]].<ref>{{cite web|title= MegaObzor about BR|url=http://megaobzor.com/forecasts-for-sports-require-professionalism-from-experts.html}}</ref> Bookmaker Ratings averages 1.2 million hits a month, 350,000 of which are unique visitors. During Bookmaker Ratings' four years of existence, they have helped refund players more than 1.4m US dollars.
In May 2016, Bookmaker Ratings created their 'Handicap Platform', which allows users to post their own betting tips on sporting events. The site also contains a section which gives readers the latest news from the bookmaking world as well as bookmakers' bonuses and a betting encyclopedia. Furthermore, Bookmaker Ratings has its own YouTube channel.
== Editor-in-Chiefs == * Bradley Gibbs (2015- )<ref>{{cite web|title= Management of BR|url=https://bookmaker-ratings.com/author/106008/}}</ref>
== Honours == * Betting Awards 2015 - Winner in nomination "Best internet portal about sports betting<ref>{{cite web|title= Betting Awards 2015 winners|url=https://www.championat.com/bets/news-2160225-opredelilis-pobediteli-rossijskoj-bukmekerskoj-premii-betting-awards-2015.html}}</ref> * Betting Awards 2016 - Winner in nomination "Best internet portal about sports betting<ref>{{cite web|title= Betting Awards 2016 winners|url=https://bettingawards.ru/ru/winners}}</ref> * iGB Affiliate Awards 2017 - Shortlisted in the category of 'Best Site in a Foreign Language<ref>{{cite web|title= Shortlist of iGB Affiliate Awards 2017 |url=http://www.igbaffiliate.com/sites/default/files/iGB%20Affiliate%20Awards%20shortlist%202017.pdf}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|1}}
==External links== * [https://bookmaker-ratings.com Official website] * [https://bookmaker-ratings.es Official Spanish website] * [http://megaobzor.com/rating-bookmakers-help-orient-in-arena-of-online-betting.html Megaobzor told] * [http://raiting-casino.com/gambling/news/319-paruyr-shahbazyan-kak-povysit-reputaciyu-bukmekerskoy-kompanii.html How to improve the betting company's reputation] * [http://360tv.ru/news/bukmekerskomu-biznesu-krizis--ne-pomeshaet-9562/ Crisis will not prevent betting business] * [https://lenta.ru/articles/2016/07/14/olinebets/ Почему блокировка Qiwi — The only way to win illegal bookmakers]

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Wan Ok Phansa |type = buddhist |official_name = {{lang-th|วันออกพรรษา}} |observedby = [[Buddhism in Thailand|Thai Buddhists]] |litcolor = |significance = |date = |duration = |date2018 = 24 October, [[Dog (zodiac)|Dog]] |date2019 = 13 October, [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]] |date2020 = 1 October, [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]] |frequency = Annual |relatedto = }}
'''Wan Ok Phansa''' ({{lang-th|วันออกพรรษา}}) (; literally "day of going out of [[Vassa]]", ออก in Thai meaning exit or leave) is the last day of the [[Thai people|Thai]]-[[Lao people|Lao]] observance of [[Vassa]]. It occurs in October, three lunar months after ''Wan Kao Pansa''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Meaning of Wan Awk Pansa|url=http://chiangmaibest.com/awk-pansa/|website=Chiang Mai Best|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
The day is celebrated in [[Isan]] by illuminated [[boat]] processions ({{lang-th|ไหลเรือไฟ}} ''lai ruea fai'', {{lang-tts|ไหลเฮือไฟ}} ''lai huea fai''), notably in [[Nakhon Phanom Province]] on the [[Mekong]] and in [[Ubon Ratchathani]] on the [[Mun River]].
The main ceremonies feature boats of 8–10 metres in length, formerly made of [[banana]] wood or [[bamboo]] but now sometimes of other materials. The boats are filled with offerings such as ''[[khao tom]]'' ([[glutinous rice]] sweets wrapped in banana leaves) and decorated on the outside with [[flower]]s, [[candle]]s and [[Lighting|lamp]]s. The boats are launched in the evening.
Additionally, some celebrants individually launch their own, smaller, vessels. Boat races also take place around this time in many places throughout the country as a way to please the [[Nāga#Buddhism|Nāga]] spirits. Along the [[Mekong]] River, people launch little hot air balloons, acting as a [[lantern]]s, around the night of Wan Ok Phansa.
Launching the boats (or the lanterns) symbolizes your wishes but also getting rid of unnecessary negative feelings.
==Etymology==
"Wan" ({{lang-th|วัน}}) means "day"<ref>[http://www.thai-language.com/id/131393 วัน wan ''thai-language.com'']</ref>, "Ok" ({{lang-th|ออก}}) means "the exit; the way out"<ref>[http://www.thai-language.com/id/131252 ออก aawk ''thai-language.com'']</ref>, and Phansa ({{lang-th|พรรษา}}) is the Thai word for [[Vassa]].
==Dates for Wan Ok Phansa==

Concerts: 5,000 | dimensions = | website = [http://www.countycenter.biz/ countycenter.biz] | publictransit = }} [[File:Westchester Couny Center December 3, 2013.jpg|thumb|Facade of the Westchester County Center]] The '''Westchester County Center''' is a 5,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[White Plains, New York]]. It hosts various local concerts and sporting events for the area. The County Center was conceived by the Westchester Recreation Commission in 1924 as a multi-purpose indoor recreational facility to host community programs and income-producing commercial events. It was designed by the architectural firm of [[Walker & Gillette]], and built and decorated in the [[Art Deco]] style. The construction project cost approximately $785,000; a $16-million rehabilitation was completed in 1988. For nearly 80 years the County Center has been Westchester's premier setting for thousands of concerts, trade shows, sports events, meetings, seminars, theatrical presentations, conventions and civic and community events. On the weekend of May 22, 1930, the Westchester County Center Grand opening gala was held, attracting thousands from all over Westchester to hear such notable musicians as the pianist Percy Grainger, Metropolitan Opera Company tenor Edward Johnson, organist Palmer Christian and more than 1,500 local choral group performers. In the ensuing years, generations of County Center audiences have been treated to performances by such greats as Judy Garland, Liza Minnelli, Joan Sutherland, James Brown, Kenny Rogers, Janis Joplin and John Sebastian, along with the Harlem Globetrotters, World Wrestling Entertainment, and the Royal Hanneford Circus, one of the longest running events at the Center to date. ==Notable events== * Grand opening was held May 22, 1930 features pianist [[Percy Grainger]], Metropolitan Opera Company tenor [[Edward Johnson (opera singer)|Edward Johnson]], organist Palmer Christian {{cite web | url=http://www.countycenter.biz/about/history.html| title=History of the Westchester County Center | publisher=Westchester County Center | accessdate=February 9, 2018}} * First Westchester Music Festival is held in July, 1930 in the newly opened center [https://www.nytimes.com/1930/07/06/archives/to-begin-organ-recitals-westchesters-summer-program-will-open-today.html "TO BEGIN ORGAN RECITALS; Westchester's Summer Program Will Open Today in County Centre", ''NY Times'', July 6, 1930, p 28.] *Governor [[Herbert H. Lehman]] winds up his campaign with an address at a rally of the American Labor party in 1936 [https://www.nytimes.com/1936/10/29/archives/lehman-windup-monday-ends-campaign-with-talk-at-labor-party-rally.html "LEHMAN WIND-UP MONDAY; Ends Campaign With Talk at Labor Party Rally in White Plains" October 29, 1936, ''NY Times''] * [[Joe Baksi]], future heavyweight contender, beat future movie actor [[Jack Palance]] (who fought under the name of Jack Brazzo) on December 17, 1940.[http://www.boxrec.com/boxer_display.php?boxer_id=041420 Boxrec Jack Brazzo aka Jack Palance] * List of over 400 boxing shows held at the center from the [[boxrec]] database.{{cite web | url=http://boxrec.com/en/locations/event?l%5Bcountry%5D=US&l%5Bregion%5D=NY&l%5Btown%5D=20769&l%5Bvenue%5D=40692&l%5Byear%5D=&l_go= | accessdate=February 9, 2018 | publisher=BoxRec | title=Locate Events}} *The [[New York Liberties]] volleyball team used the center as their home venue.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/06/nyregion/volleyball-at-center.html|title=Volleyball at Center|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=2018-03-24}} * Since the fall of 2014, it has been the home of the [[Westchester Knicks]], the [[New York Knicks]]' farm team in the [[NBA G League]]. *In 2018, it became the primary home of the [[New York Liberty]] of the [[Women's National Basketball Association]].{{cite web |url=http://liberty.wnba.com/news/msg-operate-liberty-continuing-pursue-sale-westchester-county-center-serve-teams-primary-home-2018/ |title=MSG to Operate Liberty While Continuing to Pursue Sale, Westchester County Center to Serve as Team’s Primary Home for 2018 |publisher=New York Liberty |date=February 8, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official Wheelchair Aussie Rules was originally created by Kevin Bucky Faulkner The first organised game of competitive '''wheelchair Australian rules football''' was played at the [[RAAF]] base in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] on 8 November 2015. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Hartigan|first1=Brian|title=First officially organised wheelchair Aussie Rules|url=http://www.contactairlandandsea.com/2015/11/08/wheelchair-aussie-reules/|website=Contact - Air, Land and Sea|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=abc>{{cite news|title=Wheelchair Aussie rules makes official debut in match between diggers and locals at Adelaide RAAF base|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-08/wheelchair-aussie-rules-makes-competitive-debut/6922434|accessdate=9 November 2015|work=ABC News|date=8 November 2015}}</ref>The game involved a team of wounded [[Australian Defence Force]] (ADF) personnel undergoing rehabilitation at [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]]'s soldier Recovery Centre and a [[Disability Sports Australia]] (DSA) team made up of players from South Australia. The game was organized by the ADF, [[Australian Football League]] and DSA. The final score was: DSA team 16.8.104 defeated the ADF team 14.5.89.<ref name=abc/>
In April 2015, [[Prince Harry]] whilst visiting [[Darwin, Northern Territory]] raised the profile of this new sport by participating in a game of wheelchair AFL.<ref name=harry>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Lisa|title=Prince Harry plays wheelchair AFL|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/latest-news/prince-harry-plays-wheelchair-afl/story-fn3dxiwe-1227310229360|accessdate=9 November 2015|work=The Australian|date=19 April 2015}}</ref> The game involved wounded Australian soldiers.<ref name=harry/>
In November 2015, there are plans to create a national league. <ref name=abc/>
==Rules== Rules of the game have some similarity to AFL rules for [[Australian rules football]] and include: <ref name=abc/> *Game is started by throwing up the ball in the centre of the field. *Six points for a goal, and one point for a behind. *Kicks are replaced with handballs, and handballs replaced with underarm throws. * A red Sherrin football is used, with the game split into four quarters. *Game is played on a basketball court with plastic posts at each end of the court. *Only five players from each team can be on the field at any given time. * Team is divided in backs, centres and forwards but only forwards can score.
==See also== *[[Wheelchair sports]] *[[Wheelchair rugby league]] *[[Wheelchair rugby]]

{{Infobox bandy team | team = Znamya-Udmurtiya | logo = Znamya-Udmurtiya logo.jpg | founded = {{start date and age|1931}} | folded = | league = [[Russian Bandy Supreme League]] | division = Group 2 | arena = [[Znamya Stadium]] | city = [[Votkinsk]], Russia | coach = | website = {{URL|https://vk.com/znamyaudm}} <!-- Home --> |pattern_he1 = |pattern_la1 = |pattern_b1 = |pattern_ra1 = |pattern_sh1 = |pattern_so1 = |leftarm1 = |body1 = |rightarm1 = |shorts1 = <!-- Away --> |pattern_he2 = |pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2 = |pattern_ra2 = |pattern_sh2 = |pattern_so2 = |leftarm2 = |body2 = |rightarm2 = |shorts2 = }} '''Znamya-Udmurtiya''' ({{lang-ru|Знамя-Удмуртия}}) is a [[bandy]] club in [[Votkinsk]], Russia. The club was founded in 1931 and has earlier been playing in the [[Russian Bandy Super League|Super League]], the top-tier of Russian bandy. It is now playing in the second tier [[Russian Bandy Supreme League|Supreme League]].<ref name="club">{{cite web|url= http://www.rusbandy.ru/club/25/|publisher= rusbandy.ru|title= «Знамя-Удмуртия» Воткинск|language= Russian|accessdate= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The home games are played at [[Stadium Znamya]] in Votkinsk.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rusbandy.ru/stadium/36/|publisher= rusbandy.ru|title= Стадион «Знамя», Воткинск|language= Russian|accessdate= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The club colours are white and red, likely inspired by the [[coat of arms of Udmurtia]].<ref name="club"/>
Team picture:[http://www.rusbandy.ru/pix/19770.jpeg]
Jersey depiction:[http://www.rusbandy.ru/pix/19760.jpeg]
